comment: Agree on the vanilla nose. Burn on the palate. I get the caramel and corn too.
Sweet nose, also sweet and vanilla in taste, pretty oaky with a spice of smoke. Really solid bourbon for that price.

I'm not exactly torn-up about the loss of the 8-year age statement on Jim Beam Black, because Jim Beam Black sold in Canada never actually had an 8-year age statement (international Beam Black was a 6-year-old). Regardless, its replacement is . . . sorta meh. Nice enough smell of caramel, vanilla and (fairly subtle) nutty Beam funk. Maybe some tobacco and stone fruits. But the taste is a bit thin, and leads with tobacco and Beam funk. A bit of peach, maybe. Candy corn. Lightly dry, toasty wood finish. An unremarkable bourbon, though the price is right. Beam Black is like every entry in the Beam Small Batch collection, if every entry in the Beam Small Batch collection was totally uninteresting and generic. It's Beam, it's bourbon, it's fine; the price is good ($28 in Canada on the right day, which is approaching bottom-shelf territory)--but for the same money, you'll have to pry Evan Williams Black Label out of my cold, dead hands.

Wood,wood. and wood on the nose. Some mustiness, nuts, and vanilla as well. Surprisingly smooth on the tongue. Hints of walnuts and some dark chocolate. You definitely get the standard Beam black cherry walnut cocktail. Not sure this actually is the highest rated bourbon in the world (ISWC 2016), but this has a lot of bang for the buck. Jim Beam Bonded is better, but this is more amenable to session sipping. 6/8/17
Ok.  Not great but not bad.  I like it better than regular Jim Beam.
Spicy with hints of vanilla and oak
Mid/mild flavor, seeeter/vanilla taste. My kind of flavor at a cheap price.
so far the worst bottle purchased , have a half bottle left and will try again in a month or 2 - som many others that are so much better

So, I grabbed a bottle of this about a week ago based on some above average reviews from people who’s reviews I trust.  Basically, I was looking for a reason to replace my standard mixer which is Jim Beam White Label.  This used to be called Double Aged and came in at 8 years old.  Well, I guess that was too long for the cash grabbers at Beam Suntory so they dropped the Double aged moniker and probably shortened the aging by 2-3 years and renamed it “Extra Aged”.  To quote Jurassic Park: “Clever, girl.”

As it is, the nose is typical Beam with candied corn, sweet toffee and faint vanilla.  The palate follows suit but adds a bit of oak spices while remaining slightly smoother than regular Beam.  The finish is a bit more warm than the regular white label and is medium in length- it’s still a bit too sweet.  I just wish the extra ABV and aging lead to something more noticeable on the palate.  It’s still relatively cheap (I paid $23 here on the shelves in Virginia- and while I think it mixes equally with the standard white label, I think if I’m going to switch up the ingredients in my B&C’s I’d do better by going with the Beam Bonded.  The 100 proof really adds a kick to my mixer for the exact same price.  

I don’t see myself switching brands here- I’ve been a Beam drinker since I was an infant (Mom said a little Beam on my pacifier always soothed the angry beast, lol).  3.5 stars.  Happy mixing, my friends.

A great introduction to the world of bourbon, even for a whiskey beginner. It is quite smooth for its price. You should drink it neat. But for me I usually water it down for my everyday drinks, bcs the abv is quite high for me, so I can open the flavor. 

Nosing and palate is very bourbon-y. Sweet, smooth, oak taste.
Go buy this if youre confused about which bourbon / whisky to buy

I grabbed a bottle of this bourbon a couple of weeks ago and have been making my way through it pretty quickly (I shared most of it with family). Here’s what I’ve found. 

Bottled at 43% ABV and most likely chill filtered. It’s a Kentucky straight bourbon so it’s natural color by law. This is a straight amber. It’s a NAS that formally had an age statement of 8 years. My guess is that it’s somewhere between 6-8. Not a bad price at $23. 

The nose is strong on the corn. Plenty of oak, vanilla, cinnamon and clove. Buttery rolls, orange zest and some milk chocolate. Toffee and butterscotch, baked apples, a bit of banana and almonds. It’s a very nice nose especially considering the price. Nothing really remarkable, but nothing bad either. 

The palate is more of the same with corn leading the charge. Caramel, vanilla, oak and a touch of mint. Stronger banana than on the nose and walnuts instead of almonds or maybe both. Very easy drinking and inoffensive. 

A light bodied mouthfeel that is a little thin but a little oily too. 
A medium short finish with oak, banana, walnuts and corn. 

For the price this is a solid choice. More expensive than Evan Williams Black Label ($16), but much better quality. Definitely good enough to drink neat or with a little ice, and almost too good to drown in a mixed drink. I still need to try EW White Label (which is still cheaper than this one [$18]) to compare, but this might become my go to house bourbon. A solid 3.75 factoring in the value, but could be bumped up to a 4 depending on how many I’ve had lol. 
Cheers
sample/didn't get much from this even vs the JB standby

My home bar was in dire need of a cheap mixer so I snagged up a bottle of this for $24 in DC (came with 2 tumblers, too!). As someone with limited experience with Beam over the past decade. I figured the abv and spice (according to distiller) would do nicely in an old-fashioned cocktail and maybe even enjoyable neat. 

The nose is heavy on sweet corn, caramel and punch of vanilla which for me triggered the feeling I’d struck bargain basement gold, but sadly it’s downhill after that. A thin and pedestrian mouth awaited and is bookended with a quick, hot, oaky spice but ultimately flat, blah finish.

As far as being a mixer goes, so far so goodish, but I feel a ping of regret for not just getting Turkey 101 as planned. Alas, my rabid search for a bottom shelf but respectable utility mixer continues. Free glasses though! ;)

2.5/5
If you like JB white label, this is a fine choice. If you don’t why are you buying this? I personally would rather spend the extra 3 dollars for something other than JB.
Pretty decent whiskey for the price....wish it had a little more kick though
Positive surprise really. Grilled cactus, peppermint extract, and crispy corn dog breading (sans hot dog).
A very spicy and oaky bourbon with a hot finish.   3 stars out of 5.

Nose: tannins, spice (cinnamon), a little citrus
Palate: heavy on the spice, with a hint of caramel and citrus
Water tamed the spice on the palate and balanced the nose, bringing out some floral notes.
Overall: a good-priced spicy bourbon. I like it!
Peanuts on the nose.  Needs a few drops of water to calm down the burn a bit...
Great bourbon for the price. Complex, Smokey, Spivey, with some burn.
With a splash of water, it has a little burn
Not much to say. A little smokey, and little thin. Overall inoffensive.
You're better off with Evan Williams for a budget bourbon.
this is a good bourbon to mix with coca-cola... this is a smoky, oak filled sip, that is spicy, so naturally the flavor is intensified with the soda.
Nice flavor, robust but short lived.
Well balanced and enjoyable for the price
Smoky and sweet with caramel, roasted nuts, slightly burnt buttery popcorn, lots of spicy cinnamon, and just the faintest baked apple. Light-bodied but savory, this is a nice sipper or mixer.
long sweet finish, caramel and vanilla.

This is my favorite JB juice so far. Better than the Devil’s Cut and white label for sure. Would buy again. 3.3/5
Having another go here a few days later, just as delicious this round. Well done JB.... well done.
My go to for cocktails. Makes an awesome old fashioned

Nose: The nose on first approach has strong notes of oak, some corn, and smoke lingers about as well; but overall nothing too exciting.

Taste: Once again oak is on the palate with notes of corn. It has a slight burn going down that leaves a tingling mouthfeel behind and the finish has notes of mint. Just FYI adding a little water makes this whiskey more friendly and removes that burn and adds a nutty flavor too.

Opinion: This is Jim Beam's extra aged bourbon. Usually I associate more time in the barrel with better quality whiskeys. However, in this particular instance, though I do enjoy this bourbon, I am not as impressed as I thought I would be. In my humble opinion I may actually prefer Jim Beam's White Label to this dram. Adding a splash of water did help me to enjoy it more, but though this was a fine dram, it wasn't my personal favorite. Sláinte!
Very drinkable with a medium body and very light finish.
Picante, defumado com nota de baunilha...

Nose- Metallic sweet and sour notes along with sweet peanuts. There is a kind of funkiness to it. Not bad. Just funky. 
Body- Vanilla ice cream gives way to pitted fruit with a laugh bitterness at the end.
Finish- Short and sweet. Literally.

Bright nose with some alcohol, but not as much as the Old Forester Statesman. Some citrus notes in the mouth while tasting the nose.

Warm caramel and vanilla. Expands slowly. Medium body. Quite smooth. Slight spiciness when chewing, but very little burn. Nice lingering flavor highlighted with caramel and toasted oak flavors. Good finish length in the back of the mouth.
Bought a mini bottle of this to try. It was dang good. Definitely tasted the caramel and oak. Will buy a bigger bottle of this

Mini-bottle Battle: Jim Beam Black Extra Aged vs. Jim Beam Devil's Cut vs. Rebel Yell

Devil's Cut edges out Black with Rebel Yell in a distant third.
Nice sweet vanilla finish.  This is way better than I expected for $24.  I would probably buy it again.
Nice! It's warm, oak, sirupy vanilla, friendly, still got an edge. Round, woody, full, warm, sweet, slightly sharp and pointy at the same time. Really like it. Very nice.
Pleasantly surprising. Toasted oak, vanilla, and caramel on the nose. Warm  spice, smoke, and leather on the front, with caramel and vanilla lingering all the way through to the finish.

Jim Beam Extra Aged is yet another bourbon that lost its age statement (was 8 years) in recent times, an unfortunate trend in the bourbon world right now.  So where does this Beam Black fit in with existing Beam expressions?  Let's find out!

Enjoyed neat in a Glencairn, no added water.  On the nose, a nice lightly sweet caramel with a bit of vanilla frosting and an oaky backdrop.

On the palate, somewhat thin mouthfeel, starts lightly sweet but quickly changes over to a bitter tart.  More caramel and vanilla with a bit deeper character than you expect from the lower end Beams, and accented by a bit more oaky char than usual also.  Very smooth, with just a little spice and heat. At times I seem to detect a light fruity note but it's not dominate by any means.  Probably a good place to start for beginners in the bourbon world or those looking for a nice smooth sip to ease into a session.  

Finish is somewhat long actually, producing lingering vanilla, some honey, and nice oaky smoky char. The enhanced smoky char is the best part of the sip for me.

Overall, a fairly basic Beam bourbon but the extra aging, as is typical of longer aged bourbon, produces a bit more character and depth of flavor.  I'd put the Black certainly well above White label and Repeal Batch and on par with Double Oak, but a bit below Devil's Cut (stronger oaky character I prefer), Bonded (stronger Beam peanut funk), and well below Distiller's Cut (just delicious and best Beam expression for the $).  So Black falls about mid pack in the Beam bourbon portfolio for me.  It's far from bad, just not their very best either.  It's a classic bourbon profile really, with caramel, vanilla, and smokiness in spades, but not a whole lot more.  It lacks complexity and enhanced spicy fruity or floral notes, but is super smooth and easy to pick apart the classic bourbon profile.  I feel like the 43% ABV is hurting this one a bit.  Kicked up to 47-50% I think would really bring out the bit of extra aging and take the flavors up a notch.   Not bad, but go for Distiller's Cut if budget allows, as it offers so much more feel, flavor, and kick.  Cheers!
Smoky, sweet, vanilla.  a little burn but in a good way
Tastes nice, but where’s the spice? No slap in the face here, just your average joe, smooth and drinkable. Not much to linger on here, fades fast. I expected more.
Solid oak.  No barrel bite.  Corn sweetness (duh).  Aftertaste that almost reminds me of a really mellow Scotch.
Consistently nice on the nose, but the flavor degrades fast.
Oak.  Spikey.  Boozy.  Palate is shot so I'll need to revisit another time
the strength overwhelm me. is it good, I dont know?
Starts out spicy/ peppery and transitions to a sweet vanilla caramel with a noticeable oak background. Very enjoyable.
Extra aged?  Whatever that means.  This is better than white label but a far cry from the old  8 year
Somewhere between white label and single barrel. Not bad for the price, but also not great.

So this is quite nice in my opinion.  It is surprisingly smooth, sweet, and tasty.  Enough wood, subtle spice.  Easy to chew.  

There is a signature that only Jim Beam has in their flavor profile which I do not know how to describe other than ‘Jim Beam Taste’, and I am not sure that is redeeming, as much as unique.   I think it must have something to do with the yeast they use in the fermentation steps.  

Overall, I like it.
First whisky I truly tried, but was really surprised by the taste, quite a strong after-taste, I quite like it.
Warm and welcoming from the start, with such a deep fruity taste that it almost make you wish it was not that strong.
Has a strong burn but overall enjoyable for the cost. It doesn’t have a cork so that’ll tell you something

Nose: Cherry, Carmel, Oak, Aggressive, Vanilla

Taste: Cherry, Carmel, Oakey, Cinnamon?
A peanut butter and banana sandwich with some oak as well.

Smells initially of a sweetness followed closely by an overpowering ethanol, tastes mildly of oak but also is followed by aggressive ethanol tastes.

Bought as a Jim Beam flight.
Light, inoffensive, slightly on the sweet side.
Was surprised by how much I enjoyed this. Not overly complex, but enough to make it interesting.  Would definitely try again

Nose: sweet, slightly smoky with corn and slight ethanol

Palate: hints of honey and butterscotch 

Finish: smooth with little warmth. 

A sweeter and less nutty, slightly bolder version of what I get from Evan Williams black label. Rough around the edges and only slightly better than the mainstream Jim Beam white label. I’d imagine it’s a blend of 4-8 year bourbons since it lost the 8-year age statement awhile back. Not bad for what it is. Easy to sip just not as balanced as other bourbons in the same age range.

AROMA/ Sweet, Carmel, Vanilla, Honey, Nugget
FIRST SIP/ Sweet Honey, Smooth with a bite, Smokey Wood, Sice, Oak, Burn
TASTE/ Smooth up front, Carmely Sweetness, Corn
FINISH/ Alcohol Burn, Sweetness, Spice, Oils, Honey
83 proof
This isn't my Father's Jim Beam, it is another, sweeter, and has more woodyness, you can taste the Oak, the Corn, and the smoke, it does have a bite and spice I do believe my Dad liked this... but it had the qualities of a will aged Bourbon without the AS age statement. This is D-Lish with 6 small cubes of ice to a 3 oz pour! The ice does make a change to the profile of this Bourbon adding more flavors and some Fruits and Florals! Drink with a friend or family! As always be safe and enjoy! CHEERS!!
Well balanced bourbon - really enjoyable on ice.
Pretty well balanced whiskey. I enjoy it on ice - Sue me.
Smooth full of flavor.  Extra spiced

I thoroughly enjoyed Jim Beam Single Barrel and thought I'd try one of their cheaper offerings in the $25 range. I purchased a 375 mL of this for $13.95 and I'm glad that's all I bought. This is a weak bourbon. It tastes like very watery Single Barrel even though the difference in proof from 95 to 86 may not seem that significant. Everything is muted here, I barely smell anything unless I swirl it up. I still get that peanut brittle flavor but again, more muted than Single Barrel. This is easy to sip don't get me wrong, but at $27 you can buy plenty of other easy-sipping bourbons at the same price or less. I would steer you towards Wild Turkey or Evan Williams any day of the week.

짐빔블랙 8년
향 : 카라멜, 
맛 : 바닐라, 드라이, 가벼운 버번
피니쉬 : 가벼움, 짧은 피니쉬

Nose: caramel and vanilla, grain and sweet bread, peanuts and some fruit

Palate: nutty, watery, brown sugar and vanilla, some caramel
above average bourbon, but it has a little sharp taste

Nose. Sweet possible vanilla 

Palate. Slight peat/smoke, molasses or rich Carmel 

Finish. Spicy 

Notes. Good in old fashion not terrible to sip but probably better options

The Jim Beam Black Label has a nose of creamy vanilla, oak, caramel, and corn. It is pleasant, but not powerful. The vanilla and caramel continue into the palate with a sip that is sweet with a consistency that is just thin enough to be called thin and with just enough oil to keep it from being dry. Towards the back, charred oak, pepper, and cinnamon lead to a finish where the vanilla, caramel, and oak linger for a shorter than expected time. It's got all of the classic bourbon flavors and feelings but not in a way I'll remember or crave. Excellent quality for the price and a very good introductory or well bourbon for your home bar. I would say it's something to keep on hand as it is well rounded and will be an excellent first choice for cocktails and a decent sipper, if there is nothing better on hand.
Very similar to Evan Williams Black Label in taste, age and proof but more expensive. Get the Evan Williams.

I picked this up today (looking for a house bourbon). Normally I have WT101 as my decanter bourbon.  I  received an email about "Jim Beam extra aged bourbon", so I decided to talk to the local liquor sales lady.  She told me that this bourbon was selling very well, and that Jim Beam was having a SALE......well...that played right into my decision to try it.  At 86 proof, the burn is mellow.. but there. The legs on this spirit, is like MOTOR OIL.....It looks like rain drops slowly inching it's way down the edge of the glass. The first taste, I noticed was the mellow vanilla flavor.  I thought......for the price $20.95 for a 750ml bottle, this was pretty good bourbon.  I wish I could offer a more in depth tasting...but..(due to my untrained nose and palate), this is as much as I can comment on.  For an inexpensive spirit, It seems WORTH taking a chance on. CHEERS!
Spicy. Lots of Barrel influence. Vanilla opens up.
smooth from the first drink. not real robust in taste but also lingers perfectly. not over bearing. good drink for a good price.
Thin mouth feel, a bit of oakiness and vanilla along with Beam nuttiness and a bit of yeast

On the nose, you get lighter notes of vanilla and corn with much louder notes of caramel and peanuts. The nose also has a sugar caned oak note. The sweetness really does pop out the glass. The palate is thin and not as sweet as I expected, with continuing notes of caramel and peanut, and with a much stronger taste compared to the nose of vanilla along with a hint of cherry. The finish is very short and does not have any distinct lingering note other than "generic bourbon flavor". This is a definite improvement to Jim Beam's white label if the prices are comparable in your area.

For the price point top shelf value and taste ... great sipping bourbon. Smooth enough to sip with experienced sippers, value enough to sip with those that talk the talk but can't walk ... we those guests that googled bourbon before they came over.
It’s fine. I don’t always have a bottle on hand - but when I drink it - it’s good. Def better quality then white. It’s a standard, decent, nothing special bourbon.
Easy drinking, straightforward whiskey, what you’d expect from Jim Beam

On the nose it’s sweet with a classic Jim Beam smell. On the palate there is some spice that starts to bring heat as you move to the finish. The finish starts spicy but fades quickly leaving corn. It’s okay neat but is better in an old fashion.

A little light on the mouthfeel, but the finish is where all the flavor is. Huge oak notes. The rest is vanilla, and maybe some allspice.

Nothing special. Would like to taste side by side with Evan Williams Black.

Edit: As it cools with 1 small ice cube this gets weirdly sweet. Too sweet. Dropped to 2 stars from 3.
Honey or vanilla on the nose. Palate is similar with spice, kind of like cinnamon. Little to no burn. Would drink again
Very smooth, nice smokey taste, but only a smokey taste. Nice sipper.

Hot nose, oak, apricot, corn, rich-, hot palate
H20 > burlap, oak, smooth, good mid & finish.

I really enjoy this for what it is...solid bourbon. Has that nice Beam spice with a vanilla custard note and good oak. No its not complex or special but that's ok when you just want a good pour youre not gonna ponder over. I realize there are better cheaper options but I still come back to this in my rotation
Smooth on ice, nice flavor with enjoyable sutelties
Corn and oak. Pleasant for sipping. Profile is slightly above the price point.  Wouldn't purchase for home, but happy to sip at the saloon.
Budget classic. Flagship bourbon profile. Quite better than the white in my opinion. Whether it’s just me knowing it’s aged longer or actually better. Worth it to me.

Besides this family having more hands in Bourbon than Jeff Bezos does my life this deserves all the awards it's gotten.

Vanilla and Spices come forward with light corn towards the end. Corn and leather with a sweet vanilla come together, a slight burn towards the back quickly fades into a clean/smooth medium length finish. Hints of vanilla and carmel and grain linger. 

Would use in Cocktails for the price but the balance of this most definitely deserve a heavy lean toward straight or with light ice/water to open it up. Don't think this is just another whiskey. It's not.
Still tastes like Jim Beam. Assuming it’s cold filtered as it has a bit of harsher after taste. Absent of deep flavor when first sipping.
Middle of the road. Malted chocolate, caramel corn, almost a cabernet finish.

For 18 bucks it’s hard to find another bourbon in the price range that is this smooth. The sip starts with a strong oaky flavor, a hint of leather and a peppery finish. A simple but good sipper with ice or a splash of water!

Nose is sweet pears and apples. 

Palate is classic bourbon caramel vanilla and spice

Finish is oak spice and medium short. 

As a budget bourbon it’s good but I probably prefer Buffalo Trace
Warm and smooth. Straight or mix very nice
Really smooth clean. Warm and happy
Old favorite , interesting flavor not overly sweet , slight vanilla ending in charred
Dusty nose. Rich oak on the pallet. Opened up with a couple drops of water.
Good taste and a budget option.

This year for the holidays I’m going to try a brand new whiskey every day in December. #lifegoals

Dec. 3:

I’m trying this side by side with OG Jim Beam. For Science.

The color of this is a bit darker than OG, but BARELY. A very Beamy nose, and for my money, stronger than standard. But it’s the same familiar scents: banana, leather, but of brine.

Body packs a punch. Makes OG seem mild, which is funny since OG makes the repeal batch taste mild. I’d bet this drink would make the repeal batch taste like water. While OG and RB had very similar flavor profiles, this body has a bit more. Heavy leather and nutty flavors. Some sugar and brine too. I get zero banana, which kind of blows my mind. Compared to OG, the body does not taste like a different degree of the same thing. These are very different beasts.

Finish on this is heavy on cinnamon and peppercorn. Very bitter in mouth feel too, probably from the brine. Where OG Beam finishes relatively quickly, (albeit with similar flavors and mouth feel), this little guy drags on with spice and buzz.

I don’t care for the Beam family of products so far, but of original, repeal batch, and this one, I prefer this one. Not as friendly for entry level bourboners, but far more interesting.

I don’t know if I actually have 28 more new whiskeys lined up, so if you’re reading this and there’s something readily available out there you’d like me to enjoy/suffer through this holiday season, leave it in the comments.
Not bad for what it is. Tastes good initially, but has a somewhat negative immediate after taste. I’d reserve this for a mixer, but could be a sipper in times of desperation.
Fruity oak and a smooth finish. Very good budget bourbon
Klasik bourbon. Özellikli bir tadı yok. Sert ve keskin bir içimi var
Tasty at the price point, pretty smooth and nice oak presence.
Not good. Cheap but harsh and bad
Slight burn. At first taste, Walnut.

Nose: lightly sweet, smoky
Palate: light-too watery, high smoke, mild pepper, maple wood, vanilla. Too thin. 
Finish: light, smoky char prominent, very fast finish. 
Price/taste - 14.5% excellent 
Comparable- this boy is on its own for flavor vs price. Hard to beat
One piece of ice did it real nice
Nutty, caramel, thin, lingering heat and forgettable.
Smoother than original Beam. After taste is more subtle.
A nice not too strong bourbon.
Nose: can definitely tell this is a sweeter bourbon as the smell of rye is duller in this one. Taste is some of that sweetness aided by the taste of vanilla and a light aftertaste of spice.

A bit better than original Jim Beam. The nose has some vanilla sweetness and spice. Palate is the same but the sweetness is like diluted sugar water. Everything tastes diluted but still better than white label. My go to bourbon at this price point (sub-$15) is Evan Williams BiB.
A little fuller and and sweeter than white label, very good given the price.
1st pour - Weak from nose to finish.
Corn and caramel galore with a spice finish.  Good stuff forbthe price.  Good daily sipper.
Pow! Right in the kisser. America in a bottle.
Not as much kick as I would like, but has some excellent flavours in there.

Typical ‘bourbon’ nose with caramel and vanilla sweetness.  The palate continues with a very light sweetness with notes of oak and peanuts.  The finish is quite short and somewhat forgettable. Jim Beam Black Label Extra-Aged is a decent bourbon for the price tag, but it’s lack of complexity and watered down lightness hurts this pour.

During this Great Hiatus, I have been treating myself (mostly) to mid-and-high end Bourbons – the Woodfords, Elijah Craigs, High West’s, and so forth. But today I noticed a neglected bottle of Jim Beam Black Label Extra Aged Bourbon at the back of the bar, and I decided to give it a shot. What a pleasant experience.The nose has an affect of milk chocolate and gasoline (I mean this, I think, as a good thing), and I was delightfully surprised with the taste: Smooth yet with a nice little attitude, with elements of caramel, pear, and to a lesser degree toffee and black cherry. It goes down creamy, then gets a little snarky as it hits the back of the mouth, and there is a very slightly numbing/Novocain aftertaste, but nothing unpleasant. Now, fifteen or thirty seconds later, there’s a bit of an harsh scratch at the top of the throat, but it’s only there if you gulp too big, or if you are looking for it. Really, this is a pleasant surprise, and a good thing to reach for when you don’t feel like over-thinking your choices or dealing with the often multi-layered, more complex experiences of pricier bourbon.
This pour is worth every bit of the increased age & price over the white label. I really enjoyed Black when it was 8 yr but this NAS could easily be a daily drinker.
One note flavor. Smoother than white label but probably wouldn’t buy this again vs comparable priced OGD BIB
Light and a bit creamy with flavors of caramel and a hit of vanilla. Medium finish with a little corn flavor and spicy at the very end.
Much more dry tasting than others I’ve had. Could drink a larger quantity of this than I could most bourbons
Good value. Better than white. But price does factor in here
Light with a nice dark chocolate finish.

Drink this bourbon. At a bar, at home, neat, on the rocks, in a manhattan. Doesn't matter how, or where drink it. Sneak a bottle in your golf bag, pack it for a camping trip, or keept it with you while you're at a bonfire. Just make sure you've got it near by.
Nothing fancy about it. Smooth but not great flavor

I hated Jim Beam. White label and apple were very low rated whiskies, but this one... this one is a Marvel. It changed my whole perspective of the brand. An instant favorite.

When i tasted it i wanted to score it with lower points because i am not a fan of the brand, but this was so good that i gave it the true score.

On the nose, fantastic: cola, grapes, a dim spicyness, perfumed vanilla. Letting it sit for a couple minutes will release banana aromas, caramel, banana split, banana ice cream, and wood smoke like a fireplace. Simply outstanding.

On the palate two notes, but beautifully crafted: banana and cinnamon. Finish is long, creamy and spicy. 

I really enjoyed it, i have read good reviews everywhere before tasting it and it did not dissapointed me. I rate this baby a nice 92 over 100 and i absolutely recommend it. Cheers!
Bit of spice and heat right away with some smoked corn. Some vanilla but nothing standing out. Not as smooth as I expected.
Decent, but not great. Heavy on the char.

Starts out with a reasonably sweet vanilla vein then transitions into a smooth middle with nice spice. Has a warming medium long finish where the wood comes through. Bought it as a mixer but is surprisingly good as a stand alone.
Exactly as described.    Great drink for a cheap bottle.   I would recommend to anyone

Nose: Dusty corn, caramel, a little vanilla, and oak.  Alcohol is present, though not crazy.  Bready, with a bit of rye spice coming in, with almost some mint and basil/thyme.  Maraschino cherries - the cheap kind.  Bananas, peanuts.

Palate: Exactly as expected - retains the same core notes as the nose, though the vanilla is a little more pronounced.  Not sickly sweet, but close.  Nuts, small hit of tobacco and leather.  Hershey process chocolate.  Black pepper, oak, touch of char.  Fruit cup.  Medium light mouthfeel.

Finish: Oak comes way to the front, turning the experience more dry.  Flash of texture on the tongue, then nuts, fruits, and rye spice reveal while the oak subsides.  Finish is medium short.

Other Notes: I'll take this over standard Beam white label any day - far more refined, though not necessarily the most complex thing, either.  Still, a good "background whiskey" if you're looking for a no-frills sip that won't break the bank.
Surprisingly good.  Corn, sweet and spice on the nose.  Spice, wood and caramel on the palate with a medium burn finish.
My favorite of the Jim Beam line, when it’s cheap enough.
Deeper, smoky flavor than original beam. Decent mixer but not a bargain for sipping neat. You can wow some guys at a wedding by stocking this instead of the original behind the bar.
